content: boddam copyright © general hogbuffer 2016 this design uses some elements from classic gansey style knitting and i have deliberately incorpo- rated a few elements that are found in the sweaters that have developed in fishing villages all across the british isles the name comes from one of these villages there is no real relation between the pattern and this particular village as historically patterns tended to travel along the coast but i felt it suited the socks well size i have only charted the socks for a medium which uses 72 sts due to the cables this will fit roughly like a plain sock worked with 64 sts but the simplicity of the patterns means they can very easily be adapted to any size by simply adding or removing some sts within the pattern material although cables always use a little bit more material you should be able to get a pair of socks from 100g of 4-ply sock wool for all but the very largest of sizes obviously the length of the leg will impact on the wool needed gauge on my sample i was getting 34 sts x 42 row over plain stocking stitch but take this as a guide line only make sure that the sock fits you well and that you are happy with the drape of the fabric you are creating first of all needle size i have used 2 circular needles of 2 5mm but the design also lends itself very well to dpns or magic loop i will refer to needle 1 and needle 2 in the instructions bear in mind that your arrangement may be different if you are using dpns use the size needle that gives you the correct fabric in com- bination with the yarn selected further requirements - tapestry needle - cable needle you can easily cable without a needle but the extra needle helps with the cable decreases that occur a dpn will also work - stitch markers although you could do it without if they irritate you boddam page 2 cuff cast on 80 sts and work the cuff chart on each needle row 1-9 are the set up for the first cable row 10-14 are the repeat keep working row 10-14 until you have reached the desired cuff depth ending with a row 14 leg work row 0 of the main chart this will decrease your overall st count to 72 work the main chart until you have the desired leg length please note that the different sections have different repeats the outer motifs which will form a herringbone at the side of the leg repeat every 6 row while the central motif called marriage lines repeats every 18 row see red boxes the cables in between occur every 5 row this is one of the nods to the traditional fisherman sweaters a lot of the designs ask for a cable every 5 rounds if you keep track of your work in a notebook like
